command: iptables -I INPUT -m recent --name t1205_ssh --rcheck --seconds 60 -p tcp --dport 2200 -j ACCEPT; iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -m string --string "SSH-2.0-KNOCK" --algo bm -m recent --name t1205_ssh --set -j LOG --log-prefix "T1205-SSH-SIGNAL "; nc -l -p 2200 -k >/dev/null 2>&1 &
explanation: Uses a non-standard SSH client identification string (SSH-2.0-KNOCK) as the magic signal on port 22. On match, iptables logs and marks the source to permit TCP/2200 for 60s where nc awaits. Demonstrates SSH banner-based signaling.
rationale_steps: Parse SSH banner text to trigger a short-lived allow rule
Record anomalous SSH identifiers in logs for detection
Gate a separate port behind the signaling condition

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Three well-formed commands separated by semicolons with valid iptables and nc options and balanced quoting.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: Implements SSH-banner-based signaling with iptables recent to gate port 2200 and log, matching T1205 behavior, but assumes root privileges and an active SSH listener on port 22 to be effective.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, using valid iptables options, correct string matching syntax, proper netcat flags, and appropriate command separators without any parsing errors.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: While the core logic of using an SSH banner string with iptables and recent module for traffic signaling is well-aligned with T1205, the critical claim of 'Privilege: None' renders the iptables commands inoperable without root access, significantly reducing its operational plausibility.
